texto:
We’ll use this lesson to refine our understanding of transitive and intransitive verbs.

This is crucial — because as you’ve already seen, knowing whether a verb is transitive or intransitive will tell you exactly when to add certain suffixes — especially those that mark the subject, direct object, indirect object, and so on.

If we skip this step, it becomes too easy to get confused or start applying suffixes in the wrong places.

So — let’s go back to basics, and make sure this is absolutely clear:
Transitive verbs have a direct object.There is someone or something that receives the action of the verb.
Intransitive verbs do not. The action happens, but no one and nothing is receiving it.

Intransitive Verb:
The subject → takes no suffix (This is why you’ve seen ŋarra, nhe, ŋayi used bare with intransitive verbs.)

If there is a noun or expression showing with what / by what the action is happening (like an instrument, tool, or manner), then gu / ku / wu / wa is used on that noun — as we saw in Lesson 11.

Example:
Stephen marrtjina → Stephen went
(no suffix needed — no one is being acted upon)
